articles.headline: In a Sharp Reversal, Biden Opens a Path for Ukraine to Get Fighter Jets
articles.snippet: The president told allied leaders that he would allow Ukrainian pilots to be trained on American-made F-16s, and is prepared to approve other countries’ transferring the jets to Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The president told allied leaders that he would allow Ukrainian pilots to be trained on American-made F-16s, and is prepared to approve other countries’ transferring the jets to Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden told U.S. allies on Friday that he would allow Ukrainian pilots to be trained on American-made F-16 fighter jets, moving toward letting other countries give the planes to Ukraine — a major upgrade of the Ukrainian military and a sharp reversal.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: JetBlue-American Partnership Struck Down by Federal Judge
articles.snippet: An alliance begun in 2021 at four airports in the New York area and Boston allowed the airlines to sell tickets on each other’s flights and share revenue.
articles.abstract: An alliance begun in 2021 at four airports in the New York area and Boston allowed the airlines to sell tickets on each other’s flights and share revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge halted a partnership between American Airlines and JetBlue Airways at airports in New York and Boston, writing in a ruling on Friday that the alliance would hurt competition and raise fares.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Why Dianne Feinstein, Like Many Before Her, Refuses to Let Go
articles.snippet: A life in Congress comes with power, prestige and perks that can be hard to leave behind. For some lawmakers who view their job as their identity, the prospect is unthinkable.
articles.abstract: A life in Congress comes with power, prestige and perks that can be hard to leave behind. For some lawmakers who view their job as their identity, the prospect is unthinkable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, has put on a suit nine times since 2014, when he retired after serving in Congress for 40 years. He counts.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni

articles.headline: Would You Take Financial Advice From A.I.?
articles.snippet: The financial services industry is plotting how to incorporate tools like ChatGPT into its products. But humans will still be necessary to provide personal advice.
articles.abstract: The financial services industry is plotting how to incorporate tools like ChatGPT into its products. But humans will still be necessary to provide personal advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul Weiner, an artist, has been experimenting with artificial intelligence for the past year, generating A.I.-created visual disinformation and seeing whether he can get the images to spread. But recently, he turned to ChatGPT, a chatbot that has the ability to respond to complex questions, for a much different reason: With his 30th birthday looming, he decided to ask it for advice about retirement planning.
articles.byline: By Paulette Perhach

articles.headline: Air DeSantis: The Private Jets and Secret Donors Flying Him Around
articles.snippet: As the Florida governor hopscotched the country preparing to run for president, a Michigan nonprofit paid the bills. It won’t say where it got the money.
articles.abstract: As the Florida governor hopscotched the country preparing to run for president, a Michigan nonprofit paid the bills. It won’t say where it got the money.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Ron DeSantis, Sunday, Feb. 19, was the start of another busy week of not officially running for president.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Berzon and Rebecca Davis O'Brien

articles.headline: Democrats’ Phalanx Around Biden Has an Eric Adams-Size Hole
articles.snippet: The New York mayor has loudly blamed President Biden for an influx of migrants, amplifying concerns many Democrats share but irritating Mr. Biden’s aides and weakening his political position.
articles.abstract: The New York mayor has loudly blamed President Biden for an influx of migrants, amplifying concerns many Democrats share but irritating Mr. Biden’s aides and weakening his political position.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party is following a standard strategy as President Biden seeks re-election: Do not criticize him publicly under any circumstances, lest it help Donald J. Trump or one of his acolytes take back the White House for Republicans.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Dana Rubinstein and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: Why Is Inflation So Stubborn? Cars Are Part of the Answer.
articles.snippet: Prices of new and used vehicles were supposed to recede quickly as supply chain problems dissipated. The market had other ideas.
articles.abstract: Prices of new and used vehicles were supposed to recede quickly as supply chain problems dissipated. The market had other ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: ‌Car prices soared after the coronavirus lockdowns, and two years into the United States’ worst inflationary episode since the 1980s, the industry demonstrates that getting back to normal will be a long and lurching ride.
articles.byline: By Lydia DePillis and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: There’s No Ocean in Sight. But Many Hawaiians Make Las Vegas Their Home.
articles.snippet: The scenery can’t compare. So why are Hawaiians increasingly moving there?
articles.abstract: The scenery can’t compare. So why are Hawaiians increasingly moving there?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Pauline Kauinani Souza was a child in Hawaii, she spent early mornings watering her grandfather’s watermelons and papaya trees.
articles.byline: By Eliza Fawcett and Hana Asano

articles.headline: Building Boom on Mykonos Reveals ‘Wretched’ Side of Greece’s Recovery
articles.snippet: Investors are eager to cash in on soaring demand for luxury properties, but an attack on an archaeologist investigating building violations brought a darker underbelly to light.
articles.abstract: Investors are eager to cash in on soaring demand for luxury properties, but an attack on an archaeologist investigating building violations brought a darker underbelly to light.
articles.lead_paragraph: Well-heeled vacationers descended from luxury hotels into the gleaming labyrinth of Mykonos’s historic old town on a recent evening, ogling gold jewelry and heading to bars offering pricey bottles of Veuve Clicquot. Tourists sailing the Aegean on 15-deck cruise ships ducked into designer boutiques on day trips of unbridled shopping.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: The E-Sports World Is Starting to Teeter
articles.snippet: At least two organizations in America’s most prominent league for professional video game players are selling their teams, underscoring the industry’s uncertain future.
articles.abstract: At least two organizations in America’s most prominent league for professional video game players are selling their teams, underscoring the industry’s uncertain future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, the Madison Square Garden Company, a group that includes James Dolan, the owner of the New York Knicks and the New York Rangers, announced a triumphant entrance into sports’ next frontier: a professional video game league.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning

articles.headline: After a Show-Stopping Entrance at the G7, Zelensky Pleads for More Aid
articles.snippet: He urged his supporters to stay the course and tried to convince fence sitters like India and Brazil that there is no middle ground.
articles.abstract: He urged his supporters to stay the course and tried to convince fence sitters like India and Brazil that there is no middle ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine landed in Japan on Saturday determined to urge the wealthiest democracies in the world to stick with him as Moscow bets on the West growing fatigued by the cost and consequences of the war.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Wagner Chief Says Bakhmut Is Taken; Ukraine Rejects Claim
articles.snippet: The head of the Russian paramilitary group said his forces had captured the eastern city, a claim Ukrainian officials were quick to deny even as they called the situation “critical.”
articles.abstract: The head of the Russian paramilitary group said his forces had captured the eastern city, a claim Ukrainian officials were quick to deny even as they called the situation “critical.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The head of Russia’s Wagner paramilitary group said his mercenaries had captured Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine on Saturday, a claim the Ukrainian military denied even as their soldiers have been forced into an ever shrinking patch of land inside the ruined city.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora

articles.headline: Even Flirting With U.S. Default Takes Economic Toll
articles.snippet: Financial markets are still betting that Congress and the White House will strike a deal. But the uncertainty alone is having consequences.
articles.abstract: Financial markets are still betting that Congress and the White House will strike a deal. But the uncertainty alone is having consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: As negotiations over the debt limit continue in Washington and the date on which the U.S. government could be forced to stop paying some bills draws closer, everyone involved has warned that such a default would have catastrophic consequences.
articles.byline: By Lydia DePillis and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: The U.S. Left Them Behind. They Crossed a Jungle to Get Here Anyway.
articles.snippet: For thousands of Afghans, the American withdrawal from Kabul was just the beginning of a long, dangerous search for safety.
articles.abstract: For thousands of Afghans, the American withdrawal from Kabul was just the beginning of a long, dangerous search for safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taiba was being hunted by the men she had put behind bars.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios

articles.headline: What Tim Scott’s 2024 Campaign Could Mean for Black Republicans
articles.snippet: The South Carolina senator’s bid for the White House — as the sole Black Republican in the Senate — could raise not only his profile, but those of Black conservatives across the country.
articles.abstract: The South Carolina senator’s bid for the White House — as the sole Black Republican in the Senate — could raise not only his profile, but those of Black conservatives across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott, Republican of South Carolina, addressed the Charleston County Republican Party at a dinner in February, offering a stirring message of unity and American redemption that has become the center of his stump speech. The next day, he called the chairman of the county party to ask for his support.
articles.byline: By Maya King

articles.headline: Start-Ups Bring Silicon Valley Ethos to a Lumbering Military-Industrial Complex
articles.snippet: Small, fast-moving U.S. tech firms are using the war in Ukraine to demonstrate a new generation of military systems but face the challenge of selling them to a risk-averse Defense Department.
articles.abstract: Small, fast-moving U.S. tech firms are using the war in Ukraine to demonstrate a new generation of military systems but face the challenge of selling them to a risk-averse Defense Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capella Space, a San Francisco-based start-up, is building a fleet of small, inexpensive satellites that can track enemy troops as they move at night, or under cloud cover that traditional optical satellites cannot see through.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Biden Announces More Aid for Ukraine as Group of 7 Powers Meet in Japan
articles.snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine received vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized the war-torn city of Bakhmut.
articles.abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine received vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized the war-torn city of Bakhmut.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIROSHIMA, Japan — President Biden and other leaders of the world’s major industrial democracies rallied around Ukraine on Sunday with vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized full control of a bitterly contested city.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Motoko Rich and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Sound of France’s Pension Fury? The Saucepan.
articles.snippet: Protesters have been harassing the French government in clanky demonstrations that have gone viral in a country with no shortage of kitchenware.
articles.abstract: Protesters have been harassing the French government in clanky demonstrations that have gone viral in a country with no shortage of kitchenware.
articles.lead_paragraph: Spreading across a highway so that no cars could pass, 100 or so protesters banged saucepans in a deafening racket that echoed through a remote valley outside the town of La-Cluse-et-Mijoux in eastern France last month. They were marching toward a nearby castle where the French president was due to arrive, determined to stand in his way and create cacophony around the visit.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Meta Fined $1.3 Billion for Violating E.U. Data Privacy Rules
articles.snippet: The Facebook owner said it would appeal an order to stop sending data about European Union users to the United States.
articles.abstract: The Facebook owner said it would appeal an order to stop sending data about European Union users to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Meta on Monday was fined a record 1.2 billion euros ($1.3 billion) and ordered to stop transferring data collected from Facebook users in Europe to the United States, in a major ruling against the social media company for violating European Union data protection rules.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: He Was Investigating Mexico’s Military. Then the Spying Began.
articles.snippet: While looking into abuses by the armed forces, the country’s top human rights official was targeted with Pegasus, the world’s most notorious spyware, The Times found.
articles.abstract: While looking into abuses by the armed forces, the country’s top human rights official was targeted with Pegasus, the world’s most notorious spyware, The Times found.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is a longtime friend of the president, a close political ally for decades who is now the government’s top human rights official.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: An Oil Refiner Leans on Manure to Provide a Greener Future
articles.snippet: Varo Energy, a Swiss provider of gasoline and diesel, is charting a path to lower carbon energy by relying on farm waste and used cooking oil.
articles.abstract: Varo Energy, a Swiss provider of gasoline and diesel, is charting a path to lower carbon energy by relying on farm waste and used cooking oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day dozens of tanker trucks, many laden with pig manure and other kinds of agricultural waste, rumble through the gateway of an imposing steel-and-concrete plant in northeast Netherlands.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed

articles.headline: A Year After a School Shooting, Divisions Run Through Uvalde
articles.snippet: Tensions have flared over new rifts between victims’ families and the police, and between gun owners and newly minted gun-control activists.
articles.abstract: Tensions have flared over new rifts between victims’ families and the police, and between gun owners and newly minted gun-control activists.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a school board meeting this month in Uvalde, Texas, parents and administrators found themselves locked in what had become a familiar argument: Nearly a year had passed since a gunman breached Robb Elementary School and killed 19 children and two teachers. The community was still waiting for officials to fully disclose how it happened.
articles.byline: By Edgar Sandoval, J. David Goodman and Tamir Kalifa

articles.headline: With Ban on Micron, China Escalates Microchip Clash With U.S.
articles.snippet: A Chinese government block on Micron Technology’s memory chips marks how far apart the two economic powers are drifting on tech policy.
articles.abstract: A Chinese government block on Micron Technology’s memory chips marks how far apart the two economic powers are drifting on tech policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When cutting foreign technology companies from Chinese supply chains, Beijing has long chosen to work obliquely or even secretly. Regulators would give executives back-room lectures, weigh them down with excessive red tape or hit them with occasional office raids. Rarely did the government tell a firm outright it was no longer welcome.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and John Liu

articles.headline: Companies Are Taking a Harder Line on Union Organizers, Workers Say
articles.snippet: Apple, Starbucks, Trader Joe’s and REI are accused of targeting union supporters after organizing efforts gained traction, charges the companies deny.
articles.abstract: Apple, Starbucks, Trader Joe’s and REI are accused of targeting union supporters after organizing efforts gained traction, charges the companies deny.
articles.lead_paragraph: After working for more than seven years at an Apple store in Kansas City, Mo., Gemma Wyatt ran into trouble.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber
